title: 114_hr3484
content: The Act titled "Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2016" authorizes certain leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may carry out leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for purposes benefiting veterans and their families, including supportive housing, health promotion, education, and vocational training. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may carry out leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for purposes benefiting veterans and their families, including supportive housing, health promotion, education, vocational training, peer activities, legal assistance, volunteerism, family support services, transportation, and services in support of these purposes. The lease to The Regents of the University of California for up to 10 years must focus on providing services to veterans. The Regents agrees to provide additional services and support benefiting veterans and their families during the lease term. These services may include medical, clinical, therapeutic, dietary, rehabilitative, legal, mental, spiritual, physical, recreational, research, and counseling activities. The Secretary may not carry out any land-sharing agreement at the Campus unless it provides additional health-care resources to the Campus, benefits veterans and their families, and does not generate revenue for the Department of Veterans Affairs. Revenues from leases at the Campus are to be used exclusively for the renovation and maintenance of the land and facilities. The Secretary may grant easements on the Campus for public transportation facilities and utilities, in accordance with federal laws. The Secretary may authorize easements or right-of-ways on the Campus for improvements subject to specified conditions. Any authorized easement or right-of-way will be terminated if abandoned, reverting the land to the United States. The Secretary is prohibited from selling real property or improvements at the Campus. Leases must align with the approved master plan. Compliance with relevant laws is required for leases and land use. The Inspector General of the Department of Veterans Affairs may restrict lease agreements at the Campus if non-compliance with Federal laws or mismanagement is found. The Secretary must certify implementation of recommendations before entering into new leases. The Secretary must ensure that all leases at the Campus comply with Federal laws and environmental regulations. A Community Veterans Engagement Board will be established to coordinate with the Department of Veterans Affairs and provide recommendations to improve services for veterans and their families. The Board will consist of a majority of veterans as members. The Community Veterans Engagement Board will have less than 50 percent veterans, with nonveteran members being family members, advocates, service providers, or stakeholders. The Board will collaborate with the community through public forums and focus on local issues related to health care, benefits, and memorial services. The Secretary must notify Congress and relevant committees about any leases or land-sharing agreements at the Campus. The Secretary must inform Congress and relevant committees about any leases or land-sharing agreements at the Campus. An annual report evaluating all leases and agreements must be submitted to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs, including revenue management and specified records. The Inspector General must submit reports on all leases and land management at the Campus to Congress and relevant committees every two and five years after the enactment of the Act, and as needed thereafter. The reports should assess the Department's efforts to implement the master plan for the Campus. The General must consider the latest report submitted to Congress by the Secretary. This section does not limit the Secretary's authority to enter into other agreements related to the Campus. "Principally benefit veterans and their families" is defined as services exclusively for veterans and their families, excluding services that only benefit veterans. The text discusses exclusions of services that only generate revenue for the Department of Veterans Affairs. It also includes amendments related to the Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2016.
